docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN people buy health insurance, few worry that it might run out. As long as they pay their premiums, they expect to be covered, no matter how many medical bills they rack up. After all, what's the point of having insurance if, just when you need it most, your policy shuts down like a bank at closing time? Many policies, however, do place a cap on the amount they will pay out over the course of a person's lifetime. More than two-thirds of people in preferred-provider organizations have such lifetime benefit maximums, as do nearly half of people covered by conventional indemnity plans, according to a recent survey of employer health benefits by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Lifetime caps are less common among plans offered by health maintenance organizations.
docs.abstract: More than two-thirds of people in preferred provider health insurance plans and nearly half of those covered by conventional indemnity plans hold policies that place cap on amount they will pay out over course of person's lifetime; severe illness or injury easily exceeds many plans' lifetime caps, leaving insured persons without coverage; lifetime caps are less common among plans offered by health maintenance organizations; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: WHEN people buy health insurance, few worry that it might run out. As long as they pay their premiums, they expect to be covered, no matter how many medical bills they rack up. After all, what's the point of having insurance if, just when you need it...

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would close the state's looming budget deficit by pushing some people off Medicaid, limiting others from signing up and holding the line on financing for education. He said stern measures were needed to avert tax increases that he said would block economic revitalization. Serious budget reduction must start with Medicaid and education because they are the state's two costliest programs, he said. But, he said, such proposals are ''not going to make a lot of people happy.''

headline.main: Golisano Proposes Stern Measures to Close Budget Gap and Avoid Tax Rise

docs.abstract: Independence Party gubernatorial candidate Tom Golisano says he would close New York's looming budget deficit by tightening Medicaid eligibility and holding line on education funding, in order to avoid tax increases that would hinder economic revitalization; discusses campaign positions in interview at The New York Times; photos; promises non-nonsense corporate executive's approach intolerant of back-room dealing and quid pro quos; Golisano also would push for free SUNY tuition for high school students with at least B averages, using $1.4 billion from lottery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., held that the police in Charleston, S.C., had performed unconstitutional searches by having a hospital test the urine of pregnant women for cocaine. The court answered a question left open by the Supreme Court last year when it held that the tests were subject to constitutional limitations on searches and would be lawful only if the women had consented. The appeals court held that the women did not know that their urine was being tested for evidence of crimes and that their consent was not informed consent. Adam Liptak (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Cocaine Tests Ruled Illegal

docs.abstract: US Court of Appeals for Fourth Circuit holds police in Charleston, SC, performed unconstitutional searches by having hospital test urine of pregnant women for cocaine without her informed consent (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A panel of specialists advising the government on smallpox vaccinations recommended today offering the immunization to an estimated half-million emergency room and other hospital workers because of the possibility of a bioterrorist attack. The panel chose not to recommend offering vaccinations to the estimated 10 million paramedics, firefighters, police officers and other health care and law enforcement workers who might also be among the first to respond to a biological attack.

headline.main: Smallpox Inoculation Urged For Employees of Hospitals

docs.abstract: Panel of specialists advising government on smallpox vaccinations recommends offering immunization to estimated half-million emergency room and other hospital workers because of possibility of bioterrorist attack; panel choses not to recommend offering vaccinations to estimated 10 million paramedics, firefighters, police officers and other health care and law enforcement workers who might also be among first to respond to biological attack; decision on how many to vaccinate is complicated and contentious because vaccine is dangerous and threat of bioterrorism attack that releases smallpox virus is unknown; Pres Bush is expected to make decision after reviewing several proposals; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A pregnant woman may use deadly force to protect her fetus even when she does not fear for her own life, the Michigan Court of Appeals has ruled. Legal experts say the decision has opened another front in the legal wars surrounding abortion. The court emphasized that its decision was a narrow one, concerning only assaults against pregnant women, but it acknowledged that it was entering charged legal terrain.

headline.main: Ruling Opens New Arena In the Debate on Abortion

docs.abstract: Michigan Court of Appeals opens new arena in debate over abortion by ordering new trial for Jaclyn Kurr, pregnant woman convicted of manslaughter for using knife to kill her boyfriend, Antonia Pena, after he punched her in stomach; rules that woman may use deadly force to protect her fetus even when she does not fear for her own life and that trial judge should have let her raise such a defense (M)
docs.snippet: A pregnant woman may use deadly force to protect her fetus even when she does not fear for her own life, the Michigan Court of Appeals has ruled. Legal experts say the decision has opened another front in the legal wars surrounding abortion.     The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like a lot of rock bands, the female trio Betty has had its disappointments on the road to stardom. What with shortsighted record company executives, the rigors of low-budget touring, the humiliations of opening for bigger-name bands, not to mention the internal rivalries and personal crises that arise with long association and not-so-good times, Betty has nearly come apart more than once -- evidently as recently as last year -- since it was formed in a suburban basement in Fairfax, Va., in 1985. Still, out of dedication to the music and to one another, the three women -- Alyson Palmer and the sisters Amy and Elizabeth Ziff -- have persevered long enough to tell their story onstage, which they are now doing with driving energy, blunt self-deprecation and lovely three-part harmony at the Zipper Theater.

headline.main: Women of Rock With a Tale to Tell

docs.abstract: Bruce Weber reviews show Betty Rules, featuring female rock trio Betty; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One recent Saturday at the gym, Dr. William Schaffner looked around at all the other sweaty people working out and playing basketball in tank tops. What would happen, he wondered, if some of them had recent smallpox vaccinations? What if sweat made the dressings fall off their vaccinations and they brushed up against other people? For about three weeks, the site of a smallpox vaccination can shed the live virus used in the vaccine, vaccinia, a relative of smallpox. Potentially, the virus can infect other people who come into contact with it, and some people can get quite sick from vaccinia.

headline.main: Big Question About Smallpox: What if . . . ?

docs.abstract: Dr Wiliam Schaffner, chairman of Vanderbilt University's preventive medicine department and one of infectious disease experts advising federal government, discusses unresolved issues involving smallpox vaccine; is concerned that people recently vaccinated against smallpox may inadvertently infect others; photo (M)
